awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Nano Functionalized Capacitive Deionization For Water Purification
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to further develop a technology that will unlock large new supplies of water. The technology can potentially provide a much-needed alternative to reverse osmosis (RO) for water purification, currently the most widely used technology applicable to total dissolved solids.  The proposed technology seeks to address unmet needs in water reuse, water recycling, water purification, brackish desalination, and salt-less water softening. The solution may be applicable to water quality, including water supplies impaired with total dissolved solids, nitrate, arsenic, fluoride, and other contaminants. The technology may have applications in electric grid, commercial, and industrial processes for the use of low-quality grey water, wastewater, re-used water, ground water, and residential water. Success of this project would help in mitigating environmental, social, and economic threats related to water. 

This STTR Phase I project seeks to enable optimization of third generation capacitive deionization electrodes for improved charge efficiency, energy usage, water recovery, lifetime and feed concentration.  An initial target is to remove at least 2000 ppm from a mineral- or salt-contaminated feed and recover at least 70% at low cost. Higher concentrations of water impurities will be explored to determine the operational envelope. The planned experiments intend to help quantitate how surface functionalization with ionic groups increases charge efficiency and affects important electronic properties such as capacitance, resistance, and operating lifetime. These properties will be cross checked against different feed solution concentrations, the ability to purify a given concentration of feed solution, water recovery,  and nanoscale electrode pore characteristics. Ionic molecules of different chain lengths will be tested for their ability to extend co-ion exclusion beyond mesopores into the macropore portion of capacitive electrodes. Adsorption studies will be performed to determine the number of ionic groups attached to the nanoscale electrode pore surfaces and to determine the robustness of their attachment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Mespilus Inc. successfully completed its phase NSF STTR project with Kansas State University by demonstrating advances in a 3rd generation capacitive deionization (3GCDI) system. This technology removes total dissolved solids (TDS) to purify water and improve water quality. A limited palette of fundamental competing technologies is currently in use for the target applications of brackish and low quality ground water, chiefly reverse osmosis (RO) and ion exchange. These existing technologies often waste excessive water, energy, chemicals and disposables. Improvements made during this project are anticipated to enable 3GCDI as an alternative method of TDS water purification.

3GCDI avoids the use of expensive ion exchange membranes required for efficient operation by legacy versions of membrane capacitive deionization.  3GCDI’s ability to work without membranes was achieved by attaching the same charge carrying functional groups directly onto the nanopore surfaces of activated carbon (AC) electrodes.

The functionalization was done by a simple surfactant adsorption method onto AC powder. The functionalized AC powder was consolidated with a binder into a coat-able electrode that is easy to manufacture. The functional groups were tested against leaching and proved robust. When assembled into flow cells, these electrodes showed more stable performance, with better charge and energy efficiency compared to non-functionalized electrodes. 3GCDI purification increased due to the ability to operate in polarity reversal across a wider potential range.

Operation and control at additive series voltages is important to reduce the electric current required to power the 3GCDI flow cells. This is analogous to series electronics used in electric vehicles to reduce cost and enable scale up of electric components. Therefore, a series voltage 3GCDI bench pilot was developed. Controls and electronics were designed to balance the 3GCDI cells connected in higher voltage electrical series. The resulting pilot demonstrated purification of practical amounts of total dissolved solids, electronic scalability by means of higher voltage series electronics, and flow scalability by means of a modular, stacked cell design.

In tests completed to date, this 3GCDI bench pilot purified a delta of 1,000 ppm from a 2,000 ppm NaCl solution and purified over 95% from a 500 ppm NaCl solution at 0.15 liters per minute. The figure represents >95% purification of a 500 ppm NaCl solution at 75% water recovery.  This represents key features for future scalable 3GCDI water purification machines.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/03/2024
Modified by: Marc Andelman

Image

    Marc Andelman
    3rd generation capacitive deonization (3GCDI)
